speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 13-1175, the City of Los Angeles v. Patel. Mr. Rosenkranz.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could you -- first, two questions:  Is the information that they've been keeping for 150 years the same?  Because looking at the Alderson Reporting Company requirements, the early information was basically somebody's name and -- I'm not even sure -- their address.  But today's information has -- or today's registry and requirements have information that Federal law doesn't permit to be disclosed, like driver's license, credit card information.  I mean, Federal law says you can't disclose that information. So isn't there a difference?        It's not the same tradition over 150 years.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Right.  All of the things that you say, the most effective tool for trafficking, prostitution, child molestation, none of that sounds like it's -- the purpose of the search is administrative.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Rosenkranz, are you saying then that the police can do this -- can request these records on demand, and they don't have to have any reason at all -- no reasonable suspicion, no probable cause, nothing -- because the purpose is to deter people from staying in hotels who might do bad things.  So no -- nothing like a reasonable suspicion requirement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Can you tell me how many Alderson Reporting Company prosecutions there have been -- and I use the word both criminally or civil -- for the failure to register people?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But that has nothing to do with the free right to search.  Those people who are refusing to do it are going to refuse to do it.  A recordkeeping requirement has no -- has no constitutional challenge.  What does is the unfettered access to that record.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Those people who don't want to do it are not going to do it anyway.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You -- you mean they can walk up and down the halls and see that nobody's in the certain room?  I don't know quite how you do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You have room No. 2 as if it's right there, but room No. 1204 -- Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What about my question about room 1204?  You seem to say the police can wander all over the hotel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I suppose in motels they can see what rooms have cars in front of them.  And I suppose as to room 1204 they can see, usually behind the desk what -- what keys are missing, what -- what rooms appear not to be occupied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Sure.  Why?  I mean, what you're saying is it's easier to prosecute, but it doesn't mean that you can't devote some resources and find this out.  You do a surveillance which is what police do for a lot of crimes.  And you watch people going in for two hours and leaving, and you keep a record of it.  You can even stop those people who are Alderson Reporting Company leaving to ask them. So there's a whole lot of law enforcement techniques that could be used to combat the situations you're talking about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, since when has the Fourth Amendment completely been abandoned to how effective the proof that the police can get at a moment should be?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But, Mr. Rosenkranz, why Alderson Reporting Company isn't this just like Barlow's really?  That it's not necessary on the following rationale:  Number one, most people will consent so that you go -- the police go into a hotel and say we'd like to see your registry, most people are going to consent.  If somebody says no, and there's a real basis for believing that the evidence is going to be altered or destroyed, you can seize it pending judicial review, or you can get an administrative warrant ex parte and conduct a surprise examination if you want to. So we talked about all of those things in Barlow's, about how -- why that suggested that these warrantless searches were not necessary.  What makes this different?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: What's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Go ahead.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: What's going to -- what's going to change here?  The registry is the registry, and as I said, if in an unusual case you have the feeling that the hotel is complicit, you can make sure to freeze the registry.  But that's going to be an unusual case, and mostly, the registry is going to be there. And, you know, as I said mostly people are going to consent.  To the extent not you can go get a warrant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: A month later doesn't -- you know, it -- it's an hour later.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What's the probable cause Alderson Reporting Company for the warrant?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If you haven't seen the register, what's the probable cause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What, do you have to have a policeman sit outside the hotel for -- for days to -- I mean, you don't have probable cause unless you know that there -- there are people who are, you know, in -- in the room for a short time who haven't registered.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If you prevail in this case and a member of the Court sits down to write the opinion, does he or she have to use the phrase "reasonable expectation of privacy" and say there is no reasonable expectation of privacy in our society, in our culture, in our day, or do we just forget that phrase? In -- in a way, as we all know it's circular, that if we say there is a reasonable expectation, then there is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is closely regulated another way to talk about reasonable expectation of privacy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: We talk about that in the Katz case, the telephone booth case --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't know that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I'm not sure that -- is that still a phrase that's -- that's necessary and required for us to address in an opinion like this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Whose expectation of privacy are we talking about?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not the hotel guests; right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: thought.  It's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Who --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Suppose that there's a -- Mr. Rosenkranz, suppose that there's a statute that says that the taxing authority, the IRS or the equivalent on the State level, that the taxing authority can go into businesses at any time and check payroll records; and the reason is that they need to conduct these surprise, Alderson Reporting Company warrantless searches because there's a serious problem with businesses ginning up false payroll records.  Is that constitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How about the hiring --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No.  If the government says that they do -- the government says that if you wait till they submit everything at the end of the year, they'll falsify a lot of records, and we really need to see what's happening right now on the ground in real time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: No, you do, because you don't want to give them the time to falsify things till the end of the year.  I mean, we -- we could have a thousand examples like this. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't know why not. Checking to see if people are actually registered, you don't know that until you see a person working.  So you've got a construction site.  You count the number of people; and you say, let me see your recordkeeping for your employees today.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's a real time need.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You just keep a register -- you falsify the register the way that you're saying these people would. I -- my problem with the closely held -- closely regulated is I don't see one regulation that's not applicable to virtually every public accommodation Alderson Reporting Company entity, whether it's a telephone company or a day school or a hospital. I mean, virtually all of these requirements that you list are part of the normal State regulation of entities that serve people. Is it your position now that once we say this is closely regulated, that everything is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- that serves the public in some way?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Dreeben.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, that doesn't seem very significant.  I mean, it -- it could well involve entry into a drawer.  We wouldn't normally say, well, because you can -- our rule is not simply because you can get into a house, for example, that you're free to rummage through desks.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  You're Alderson Reporting Company saying that if a police officer stands outside a house and says, bring me whatever it is I want from inside, and he brings it out, that's not a violation of the Fourth Amendment because he, under compulsion, tells the person you have to bring me what's inside, because I can't enter under the Fourth Amendment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So that's the point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: This is a facial challenge. Now, are there any or a substantial number of instances in which the application of this statute would be constitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but then you don't need the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: There are exigent circumstances.  You can get -- get a warrant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So that doesn't work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't think -- I don't Alderson Reporting Company see why we've ever required more.  All we've required is a person to say, this is my business record. And why do they have to prove more?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What -- what are they suppose to prove, that they don't use -- that they don't show it to anyone else?  We've never required that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, there is today when the Federal law requires that you not disclose credit card information and driver's license information and these registries contain that information.  So you can't have it both ways.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The registries --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- by law are required to have the driver's license information taken for people who are paying cash --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- and requires the credit card information of people who are otherwise registering. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah.  I -- I assume that, you know, if the problem is license plates and credit card information and all of that, it's not up to the hotel to complain about that invasion of privacy.  It's up to the guests, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And this case does not involve the guests.  It's just the hotel who's objecting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How -- how do you distinguish -- is it Marshall and Barlow? Do I -- do I have the right name?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I guess I don't understand that, Mr. Dreeben.  You're saying that it makes a difference constitutionally whether you keep the registry at the front desk or in the back office?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, if I were running a hotel, I think I might have -- prefer to have two uniformed detectives in the backroom so the guests don't see it.  I think it's quite intrusive.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Dreeben, I'm trying to figure out what do you think is relevant here; so let me give you a hypo, which is say that it's not a hotel, but it's a hunting lodge.  And there are recordkeeping requirements about how much people shoot and when they shoot them and what they shoot, and so forth and so on. And the fish and wildlife service or some state Alderson Reporting Company equivalent of that says, we do not -- we do not want to rely on people reporting this to us at periodic points, we just want to make spot inspections, surprise inspections, all the time.  Would that be all right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is this a public hunting lodge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: It's a private hunting lodge, this was a private hotel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that's a big difference, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Wait, that's how you're going to distinguish it, Just because it's more important?  Because the fish and wildlife people think that it's really, awfully very important to make sure that all these rules are -- are complied with. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There -- there -- there is no dispute here that you can require the hotel to keep the records.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think there would be a big dispute with regard to private hunting lodges, whether you could require them to keep the records.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I -- I think it's even more dangerous. Look at almost how many businesses, retail businesses transact their recordkeeping in public areas. Talk about any shop in the country. They don't go to the back, virtually any of them, and transact their business, keep their credit card information. They put it right on the computer in front of them. So, I mean --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So it can't be that merely ask -- intruding on someone's private information, in a public place eliminates the Fourth Amendment.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Goldstein. ORAL ARGUMENT BY THOMAS C. GOLDSTEIN ON BEHALF OF RESPONDENTS

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is it -- is it your position that there is no instance in which this statute and the -- the implementation of it would be constitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose that a city or a State wanted to establish an administrative inspection regime along the lines of Barlow's?  What would it -- what would it have to include in your judgment?  Could they -- could the warrant be issued by an administrative law judge --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Would it have -- would it require probable cause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Could they -- could it be done without prior notice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Could you have different standards for different types of hotels?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Periodic inspections for all hotels, but much more frequent inspections for hotels that rent by the hour, hotels that have a large number of guests who pay in cash, and so forth?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: All those things could be done.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Now if that's okay, it's really not clear to me what that would add to the ordinance that we have before us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, what would be the nature of the objection?  I'm going back to Mr. Rosenkranz's answer to my question.  He said, the -- Alderson Reporting Company there is no notion of probable cause, reasonable cause. The hotel owner is required to keep these records and the -- that's not disputed.  They're each required to keep them.  And so -- and the police don't have to have any reason. What would be -- what would be shown by some kind of a hearing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, what's the purpose -- you agree that it's constitutional to require the registry?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Okay.  Why is the State interested in requiring the register if it can't go look at it with little notice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What's the point?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Seeing the light on doesn't prove anything unless you know that the hotel has not registered the person who is in the room.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They -- they -- they could fill in.  While he's running off getting his subpoena, they fill in who was in that room.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no -- sorry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He has it in his pocket?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All you're asking for, all this litigation, is just that the one who wants to inspect it just pulls out a piece of paper and hands it to him and that makes it all okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He could say the same thing without the subpoena.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And I thought --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It allows him the opportunity, while the policeman is getting a subpoena, to fill in the name of the person in what is otherwise a blank space.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, I thought you said that if he serves a subpoena, the other person can demand judicial -- pre-enforcement judicial review.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So the police officer has to go somewhere to get the judicial review with whoever the hotel owner sends.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it is important to the hypothetical because we're trying to figure out how this works.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The policeman goes with a subpoena and the hotel owner says, I object.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Now what happens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And how long does it take?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.  They go somewhere.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.  During that time, doesn't the hotel clerk take his pen and say, I didn't register this guy in room 2, I'm going to get in trouble, and he fills in whatever is left to be filled in.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So in a standard Alderson Reporting Company construction subpoena, if you object and say, well, I'm going to take these records and keep them in the police car trunk until we resolve this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: There's authority for that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: There's authority from this Court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems to me that's much more intrusive than the scheme you're objecting to.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: They're not entirely Alderson Reporting Company private records --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- they're records required by law to be kept and you are not objecting to that at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Goldstein, I thought --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you said they could be -- they can be -- they can be sequestered by the police officer, they even answered before, that suggested you have to have some outside approval.  But now you're saying if the hotel owner says, you can't have these records, the police can say, give me the books and take them away.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: That's a seizure.  That is a seizure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So why is that justified and looking at the information not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Yeah, that's if it has probable cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I'm confused by your answer. I thought you said in response to my earlier questions that the city could have a regime under which an Alderson Reporting Company administrative law judge issues a warrant, not a subpoena --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- for a periodic inspection.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So the -- the officer would have the warrant, would go to the hotel, here's the warrant, this is your periodic inspection.  There would be no pre-judicial review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The complexity of the answers and, frankly, the surprise I have at some of your answers may indicate that this is not a basis for a facial -- this is not a case for facial attack.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Seems to me we have to go back and -- and decide these issues on a case-by-case basis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  I thought Alderson Reporting Company the stronger answer would be we've always looked at a lack of procedural protection under a facial challenge --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: We did.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Exactly.  So anytime that the challenge as to the lack of process --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- we've looked at it, facially or as applied or whatever, but it doesn't need to be as applied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would you -- would you -- Alderson Reporting Company you've constantly said that one of the objections that the hotel owner can make is that you want these records for enforcement of the criminal law, right?  You say that's bad.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the whole purpose of this thing is to enable the criminal law to be enforced, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I think there may be an exception to that principle where the whole purpose of the scheme is to enable the detection of criminal activity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And then the objection would be the whole scheme is bad.  You cannot require them to keep books because its whole purpose is to detect criminal activity. But that's not what you're arguing.        You're saying, they can keep the books in order to detect criminal activity, but if they request the book in order to detect criminal activity, it's bad.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That doesn't make any sense at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, what is -- what is the argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And, Mr. Goldstein, I had thought that an equally important purpose behind these laws is to -- as you said earlier, prevent harassment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Prevent, I don't like this hotel owner, I want to drive this hotel out of business, I'm going to be showing up in his lobby every day. But that's part of what's going on here, isn't that right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Have we used that phrase before?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Tranquility.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We talk about privacy and all that, but I'm not sure that the Fourth Amendment should be expanded to protect the sense of tranquility.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I have a problem imagining tranquil hotel owners.  It's not what I associate with owning a hotel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do -- I think there's some rule -- at least they do it, I mean, in Alderson Reporting Company hotels, they have these notices posted all over about where the first emergency exit is and all that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Could police come in and check to make sure the hotel has those posted --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- without any type of a warrant?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I don't know -- is the back of a hotel room door -- I mean, is that a private place?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no, I'm talking about every hotel room --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- has one of those --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Can they go and say, look, you know, this is a very important thing to make sure people don't die in a big fire, we're going to make Alderson Reporting Company sure you've got them.  Check -- let me go look in room 12 where nobody is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: This is -- I didn't quite understand your answer about harassment.  Maybe it's because -- maybe this is in the record or maybe it's because this wasn't as applied.  But the police -- even if this ordinance were invalidated, the police could show up whenever they wanted, couldn't they, and ask for the -- the owner or the person at the desk voluntarily to disclose the register so there could be -- they could be in the lobby as much as they want.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So exactly what does -- how does this aid in harassment of hotels? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No, but it's a private -- it's a public space.  I don't know whether it's dispositive, but it's of some relevance. So they walk in -- there are two scenarios; one, with the ordinance, one, without.  Without the ordinance, they walk in and they said, would you, in the kindness of your heart, let us look at the register. And the owner says, no, I don't want to.  And then they come back the next day and they do the same thing. Okay?  That's the first scenario. The second one is, they come in and they say, let us see the register.  You show them the register, and what?  It's a harassment because they sit there for a while and the guests coming in see the police in the lobby?  I just don't understand factually.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I think that's -- if you had such a case-specific example, that might be one thing.  But maybe it would help if you can tell me what goes on in this pre-compliance judicial review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So the hotel owner says, sorry, you can't look at the registry, I want pre-compliance judicial review.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What is the nature of that review?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And those are the only objections that would be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- successful, harassment and using this for law enforcement? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How many of these Courts' precedents involves a business that has been treated like a public utility?  I mean, there are requirements for hotels, how big the room has to be, how many people you can put in the room, even in -- in many locations, how much you can charge for the room. The hotel owner is not like the -- like a private business.  He is a regulated provider of -- of public services that has traditionally been regulated closely over the years.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But I think the question that Justice Scalia is asking is, is there a reason to think that hotels are a more heavily regulated industry than all the other industries that we can think of?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But innkeepers have been Alderson Reporting Company regulated, not for decades, but they've been regulated for centuries and they have -- they have duties to the public that are enforceable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I'm just puzzled by this case.  You concede that the records have to be kept.  There are very few reasons for keeping those records other than law enforcement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Motel 6 does this?  Jeez, I've never -- I've never received anything from them. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: My goodness.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Once again, you're not complaining about the privacy interests of the guests. That's not your complaint here.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: 99.4 percent jurisdictions, does that include -- are you comparing the little hamlet in Indiana with Los Angeles or New York?  Does New York City have something like this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- you're -- you're saying, oh, the hotel has a private interest because it wants to know who its customers.  But they can do that by keeping their own record consensually.  You have conceded that they can require the information as a matter of law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that means it's true. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: A subpoena -- a subpoena is worthless when what is sought is something that can be easily destroyed, hidden or falsified.  It's -- it's very useful if you're trying to get complicated records that can't be easily altered between the time when the subpoena is issued and the time when the subpoena is enforced.  But nobody -- nobody issues a subpoena for the murder weapon that one is -- you know, that you suspect is in somebody's house. So these records are more like the murder weapon where there's something that can be easily falsified.  You -- you seem to concede when you say that the police can seize them, then -- then the subpoena is worthless.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You think -- you think payroll records in general are no more complicated than the ledger at a motel that runs by the hour?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Four minutes, Mr. Rosenkranz.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that's -- that's not the statute.  I didn't understand those examples because some of those examples, the police could act without this -- without this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Without this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm still very confused about this.  There is always a potential exception to a warrant, even a Fourth Amendment warrant of going into the home, exigent circumstances, there's someone sick on the other side, if there's a fleeing felon into the place, but that doesn't eliminate the need for a warrant.  It's not a tell-us-later issue.  Police can't just keep going in and then fish around for an excuse. That's a process issue. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're entitled to a warrant, you're entitled to a subpoena, you're entitled -- that's what they're challenging, which is they're not challenging all of the other reasons why the police could go in legitimately --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- with an exception to the Fourth Amendment.  They're asking whether this kind of search, generally, without all of those other exigent circumstances or other Fourth Amendment exceptions is constitutional.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Is the process here right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You know something, but that's a different issue.  It's in the public.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And how often do you think that's going to happen?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, but then it's not a search at all.  And, once again, it's not this statute that's doing the work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You're saying that they have no expectation of privacy.  We wouldn't -- we wouldn't say it's a search at all, and the police can take it away.  It doesn't depend on this statute.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, our questions intruded on your rebuttal time.  Why don't you take an extra minute or so.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted. Alderson Reporting Company
